header.title: Red Rûna: Shorter Works Vol. IV (1987-2001)
header.category: Western Esotericism, Occultism, Left-Hand Path, Runic Magic

central_thesis: This collection of shorter works by Stephen Edred Flowers primarily serves to articulate and distinguish his personal esoteric philosophy, particularly that of the Rune-Gild rooted in Germanic tradition, from other prominent Left-Hand Path currents, especially the Temple of Set and LaVeyan Satanism. It explores historical occult concepts like 'Baphomet' and reincarnation, providing a contextual and critical analysis of various magical systems and their underlying philosophies.

structure_content.summary: Explains that the essays in this volume, originally written for Temple of Set publications, have been revised and expanded for a broader readership. It specifically contextualizes the 'Offshoots and Parallels' chapter as a previously unused chapter from 'Lords of the Left-Hand Path' and 'Contra Templum' as a statement clarifying Flowers' philosophy in relation to Setianism.

structure_content.chapter_title: Another Theory on the Origin of “Baphomet” (1987)
structure_content.summary: Investigates the name 'Baphomet' from a magical and historical perspective, linking it to the Knights Templar and a specific magical square ('Satan Adata Nata S'). The author connects 'Baphomet' etymologically to the Latin phrase 'B A fomitem habemus' ('from the letters B and A we have the igniter of fire'), tying it to primal creative fire and the 'fyrfos' symbol (Maltese Cross, 'talking head'). It also explores the dualistic and Gnostic implications within Templar practices.

Challenges the popular 'New Age' notion that ancient Egyptians believed in reincarnation, arguing that this assumption stems from Western historical parallels with Indian doctrines. Citing academic Egyptology (Lexikon der Ägyptologie), the author asserts that Egyptian sources do not confirm a doctrine of metempsychosis similar to Indian karma, despite possible beliefs about the deceased appearing as animals.

Defines and differentiates 'natural' (regularly-occurring organic/mechanical processes, derived from Latin 'nasci'/'gen-') and 'non-natural' (spirit, isolate intelligence) religious systems. Flowers argues that the Left-Hand Path recognizes and cultivates this distinction for individual 'Becoming' and freedom, contrasting with the Right-Hand Path's tendency to subordinate self-awareness to a universal objective model. He posits that non-natural religion aims to 'exercise divinity'.

structure_content.chapter_title: Offshoots and Parallels of the Lords of the Left-Hand Path (1993)
structure_content.summary: Examines various Left-Hand Path and Satanic groups that emerged from the 1960s to 1990s, often influenced by Anton LaVey or having independent roots. This section covers 'The Process' (analyzed as a 'right-hand path theology dressed in Satanic imagery'), brief mentions of other 1970s sects, 'The Order of the Black Ram' (focused on 'Aryan' Satanism and deification of man), 'The Ordo Templi Satanas' (philosophically centered on 'Apostasia' or separation and the 'Will to Power'), and 'The Werewolf Order' (emphasizing the 'Beast in Man', Ragnarök, and an anti-human overpopulation stance).

Describes 'Woodharrow,' a 30-acre estate and a dedicated Hall building, as a tangible manifestation of the Rune-Gild's work and the 'Word Rûna.' This space, located near Austin, Texas, is explicitly stated as an establishment of Rûna, distinct from Setianism. It serves as a platform for ritual workings, seminars, and workshops sponsored by the Rune-Gild, aiming to extend the 'Utterance of the Word Rûna' into the objective universe. 'Woodharrow' is etymologically defined as 'the altar, or temple, of inspiration'.

Provides a clear articulation of the differences between Flowers' Rune-Gild philosophy and the Temple of Set's tenets, from his perspective as a former Initiate and Magus of the Temple. Key distinctions include the Rune-Gild's reliance on an objective, traditional, culturally- and mythologically-bound (Germanic/Odinic) set of teachings and its emphasis on 're-inclusion' of the psyche into a cultural matrix, versus the Temple of Set's intentional lack of objective tradition, focus on individual self-creation ('Xeper'), and emphasis on 'separation' as an end in itself.

Lists academic and occult sources referenced throughout the collected works, including writings by Apollonius, Michael A. Aquino, William Bainbridge, Robert DeGrimston, Arthur Lyons, Ragnar Redbeard, Ed Sanders, Nikolas Schreck, Idries Shah, and Maury Terry.

key_concepts.definition: Interpreted as a dualistic symbol and 'talking head' associated with the Knights Templar, derived from a magical square, and etymologically linked to 'B A fomitem habemus' (Latin for 'from B and A we have the igniter of fire'), symbolizing primal creative force.

A philosophical distinction between that which arises from organic/mechanical processes of the objective universe (natural) and that which pertains to isolate intelligence or spirit (non-natural). The Left-Hand Path cultivates this distinction for self-Becoming.

A path focused on cultivating and nurturing isolate intelligence as a separate, unique quality to achieve individual Becoming and freedom, characterized by separation from the objective universe. The author distinguishes his Rune-Gild approach from other LHP interpretations.

A traditional school founded by Stephen Edred Flowers, based on the 'Word Rûna' and rooted in Germanic mythology and the worship of Odin. It emphasizes an objective, culturally-bound tradition, disciplined 'Rune-Work' (e.g., 'Nine Doors of Midgard'), and the 're-inclusion' of the developed psyche into a host cultural matrix.

The 'Word' or encapsulated seed-form of an all-encompassing philosophy, representing the essence of the Mystery of the Universe revealed to Odin. It is an 'Utterance' meant to manifest tangible, permanent effects in the objective universe, with 'Woodharrow' being one such manifestation.

A psychecentric Left-Hand Path system primarily articulated by Michael A. Aquino, focused on 'Xeper' (self-creation and Becoming) through 'separation' of the individual psyche from the objective universe. It is characterized by a lack of an established objective tradition, relying on individual articulation of philosophy.

A 30-acre estate and building dedicated to Rune-Gild ritual workings, seminars, and workshops. It is a physical manifestation of the 'Word Rûna' and is defined as 'the altar, or temple, of inspiration' (from Old English 'wôd' meaning inspiration and 'hearg' meaning temple/altar).
A philosophical concept, particularly from the Ordo Templi Satanas, meaning 'standing away' or separation, leading to the exercise of the 'Will to Power' and the declaration of 'I am a god'.

practical_system.description: The book details the philosophical and theoretical underpinnings of the Rune-Gild system, emphasizing its organic connection to Germanic ancestry and mythology. It is presented as a Traditional School focused on the 'Utterance of the Word Rûna,' leading to individual 'Becoming' through disciplined exercises and the creation of 'objective products.' The 'Woodharrow' location serves as a physical hub for this work. While not a step-by-step manual, it outlines the core principles for a practitioner. The process involves moving from irrational inspiration (od) to objective work in the Runic symbol system and Odian myth, culminating in subjective realization and integration.
tools: Nine Doors of Midgard (implied as a program of systematic exercises)

relevant_quotes.text: The article entitled "Offshoots and Parallels of the Lords of the Left-Hand Path" was originally written as the eleventh and final chapter of the book Lords of the Left-Hand Path. (Rûna-Raven, 1997). This chapter was not used in the final version of the book because it seemed that there was a "disparity of magnitude” between the groups and philosophies discussed in the other ten chapters and the ones analyzed in this final chapter. However, there are some interesting ideas contained in this material, which will be found of interest.

In this context Hardenberg gives a solution to the name "Baphomet" as a Latin phrase B A fomitem habemus: "from the letters B and A we have the igniter of fire” (from Latin fomes: “touchwood, tinder” used to ignite fires).

The Left-Hand Path solution is simpler. It teaches that the two categories we are capable of perceiving as being distinct from one another are in fact just that— distinct. The distinction is the result of the existence of the principle of isolate intelligence within the Universe, and the presence of the Gift of that Intelligence within individual members of the human species. The Left-Hand Path solution is then to cultivate and nurture this intelligence as a separate and unique quality, that it may Become. Becoming leads to individually-determined freedom.

The Gild was founded at the very end of 1979, and had developed most of its major tenets and even its basic structure and forms of work before 1984. However, it must also be said that the Gild remained, and to some extent remains today, a flexible, unfixed system eternally open to whatever mysteries might be revealed along the way. It has not been derived from any other recently formed doctrinally bound system, and so it remains unfinished in some regards.

The Temple's system emphasizes the process of separation of the individual psyche from the surrounding elements of the objective universe. This act of progressive separation becomes an end in and of itself... The Gild, while seeing the utility of the formula, emphasizes the necessity of including the psyche into the host matrix of the individual (his or her culture) in order to ensure its strength and viability, and, if necessary, its transformation in times of Need.

critical_analysis.relevance: This book is highly relevant for understanding the evolution of modern Left-Hand Path philosophy, particularly in North America, by providing direct insight into Stephen Edred Flowers's Rune-Gild system and its differentiation from the Temple of Set. It offers a critical historical perspective on groups like 'The Process', 'Order of the Black Ram', and 'Werewolf Order', contextualizing their philosophical underpinnings. The essays on 'Baphomet' and 'Egypt and Reincarnation' demonstrate a scholarly approach to debunking common occult misconceptions and providing historically grounded esoteric interpretations. The work underscores the importance of an objective, culturally-bound tradition in contrast to more subjectivist LHP approaches.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The target audience includes advanced practitioners and academic scholars of Western Esotericism, Occultism, and specifically the Left-Hand Path. Individuals interested in Rune magic, Germanic paganism, the history of Satanism, Setianism, and the philosophical distinctions between various magical traditions will find this text valuable. It assumes a foundational understanding of occult concepts and the historical context of groups discussed.
